title: Self-Compassion for Neurodivergent Minds
description: A self-compassion routine based on Kristin Neff and Christopher Germer's research, designed for ADHD and autistic individuals. Uses evidence-based techniques to recognize self-criticism, develop a compassionate inner voice, and integrate self-compassion practices into daily life.

setupSteps.question: What's your biggest self-compassion challenge? (recognizing self-criticism, being kind to yourself, or believing you deserve compassion)
What time of day do you feel most open to self-reflection?
What's your preferred way to practice self-compassion? (writing, speaking out loud, meditation, or physical gestures)
What helps you feel safe and supported? (specific phrase, physical gesture, memory, or person)
What's one thing you'd say to comfort a close friend who was struggling? (This will be your 'compassion template')

steps.message: üíõ Self-compassion time! Let's work with your ${mainCompassionChallenge} using evidence-based strategies designed for neurodivergent brains.
üìù Self-criticism check: Use your ${compassionMethod} to identify one self-critical thought you had today (no judgment, just awareness)
üîç Origin exploration: Where might this inner tone come from? (past experiences, neurotypical expectations, etc.)
üí≠ Emotional needs: What would you have needed emotionally in that moment? (understanding, support, patience, etc.)
‚úÖ Celebration: 'I'm learning to recognize my self-criticism with kindness!' (your neurodivergent brain is building awareness)
üíõ Self-compassion time! Your brain is learning to recognize self-criticism. Time to develop your compassionate voice.
üë• Friend perspective: Imagine a friend having the same self-critical thought. What would you say to comfort them?
üíå Self-message: Now write that same comforting message as if you were writing to yourself (use your ${compassionTemplate} as inspiration)
üîä Compassion practice: Read your message out loud or silently using your ${compassionMethod} and notice your emotional reaction
‚úÖ Celebration: 'I'm developing a kind inner voice!' (your neurodivergent brain is building self-compassion)
üíõ Self-compassion time! Time to integrate self-compassion into your daily life.
üåÖ Morning affirmations: Say 3 compassionate affirmations to yourself (e.g., 'I'm a human being with flaws and strengths - and that's okay')
ü§ó Throughout the day: When you need it, place your hand on your heart and repeat one of your affirmations (use your ${safetyAnchor} for support)
üåô Evening compassion review: How did your day go? Were there moments when you were kind to yourself? (no pressure to be perfect)
‚úÖ Celebration: 'I'm building a compassionate relationship with myself!' (your neurodivergent brain is learning self-acceptance)

effect.taskDescription: Create your personalized self-compassion toolkit: list your favorite affirmations, compassion practices, and self-kindness strategies that work for your neurodivergent brain

effect.message: üí° Neurodivergent Tip: Remember, self-compassion is a skill that takes practice! Your brain is learning to be kind to itself. If you slip into self-criticism, use your ${safetyAnchor} and start fresh.
